newsitem.title: USA: KCBT wheat ends mostly lower in erratic dealings.
newsitem.headline: KCBT wheat ends mostly lower in erratic dealings.

text.p: KCBT hard red winter wheat futures reversed in late trading and dropped to a mostly lower close in erratic dealings pending a more accurate determination of crop losses due to a recent freeze in the U.S. Great Plains hard red winter wheat region, traders said.
"It will still take two weeks to settle on the guesstimates of freeze losses," a trader said. "You can hear everything and anything and that's why the market was so erratic."
Fresh 10-month highs were set early on concerns about harsh weather in several key wheat producing regions.
Some traders said a report that U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said there was no damage to the Kansas wheat crop north of Interstate 70 may have weighed on the market.

Advances in early trading were led by flooding in the northern U.S. spring wheat growing region, persistent reports of crop losses from a recent freeze in the U.S. Great Plains hard red winter wheat region and apparent worsening drought conditions in key European wheat growing areas.
Nearby May set a new 10-month high of $5.14 per bushel, just below the $5.17 set on June 18, 1996. The contract high for May of $5.75 was set on May 8, 1996.
A new contract high was set early in the day in the September at $4.98, above the previous high of $4.81 set Friday.
KCBT hard red winter wheat futures closed five cents lower to one cent higher, with May down five at $4.94-1/2 and July down 1-1/2 at $4.79-1/2.
Traders cited the loss in Kansas City in its spread relationship with Chicago soft red winter wheat and Minneapolis spring wheat futures.

"This has forced the market to look at the world situation, especially French wheat and U.S. spring, and I think this is why Chicago and Minneapolis gained on Kansas City today," a trader said. "It's a fast track in here and very erratic, very emotional."
KCBT wheat futures volume was estimated at 66.925 million bushels, above the 61.850 million traded Friday.
